title: Are the vocal music of the Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque period still relevant at the present time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not sure what you mean by “relevant.” They are still very beautiful, if that is what you like in music. Music after the Baroque still grows and develops from patterns laid down in those earlier periods. They can still be a challenge to singers, a showcase for their art. I mean, shit, yes, Josquin, and Hildegard of Bingen, and Purcell and the rest are as relevant as music can be, and for pitys sake, BACH!? Would you really contend that J.S. Bach’s music, vocal or otherwise, is somehow not “relevant” today?

They're a heck of a lot more relevant than some '80s pop music, which sounds more dated than just about anything. You ask if Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque music’s still relevant, and yet it's in movie scores, TV miniseries, ringtones, TV ads, and even children's cartoons. It's sampled and repurposed in awful pop tunes. You just don't recognize it, unless you're a fan.

already for the mere fact that we are talking about it I would say yes. if this repertoire has come down to us there will be a reason. We are talking about music that dates back to 1200 and certainly people do not whistle it in the street but nevertheless it is performed and has its own programming circuit and also circulates via cd and dvd.

No, except for music historians. Our modern pop music is heavily influenced by black African music and rhythm (jazz, blues, soul, rock n roll, reggae, hip-hop etc). There was no African music in Europe during medieval or early modern times.
I am not sure that much Early Music has much relevance to modern civil rights and social movements. Bach did compose a cantata about people who craved their coffee.
